718346f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Pond.
718346f-a.text:
Central Park--The Pond: A girl feeding the swans.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume
"Portrait of N. Y.' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
718346f-a.folder: Central Park & The Pond., Manhattan, NY

718262f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Terrace Fountain and the Lake - The Mall.
718262f-a.text:
Central Park, the Mall: Bethseda Fountain, on the shore of the Lake
(eastern bay), above the Esplanade at the nothern end of the
Mall. The design is by Miss Emma Stebbins, a New York sculptor:
and represents the angel blessing the waters of the pool of
Bethseda. In her left hand the angel holds a branch of lilies,
emblem of purity. The four figures supporting the basin symbolize
Temperance, Purity, Health, and Pesce.
May 1892.
Ewing Galloway.
718262f-a.folder: Central Park & Terrace Fountain and the Lake & The Mall., Manhattan, NY

717404f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street (West)
717404f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from West 34th Street. The
buildings to the left of the center were removed for the
Macy Dept. Store. The Herald Souare (formerly Park)
Theatre is at the N. W. corner of 35th Street. In the
block above is the Hotel Marlbbro. On the right appears
the Metropolitan Opera building.
About 1901
H. N. Tiemann, photo

732438f-b.title: Occupations - Peddlers - Food - Fruit.
732438f-b.text:
Peddlers, Fruit: A market scene on Ninth Ave., near West 40th
Street, showing a retail general produce area. This is a set of 2 views.
1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.P.S.

726358f-c.title: Queens: Colonial Avenue - Nassau Boulevard
726358f-c.text:
110-14 - 110-16 Colonial Avenue, east side, south from Nassau
Boulevard (to be constructed at right of house in foreground). Van
Doren Street is seen in the foreground. This set of three views
shows the De La Carte living quarters and Inn. of 1922. It was
erected by John Heeg who kept a roadhouse. Arthur Mayer owned it
in 1897. He was followed by William Gier.
Jan. 1924.
Views 2631May 1926.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
726358f-c.folder: Colonial Avenue & Nassau Boulevard, Queens, NY

716608f-a.title: Manhattan: Bayard Street - Chrystie Street
716608f-a.text:
Bayard Street, south side, west from ChrystieAto the Bowery, showing
in the foreground a 3-story frame house, No. 17 Bayard Street, that also bore
No. 11 Chrystie Street. This building was demolished in 1929 and an empty
1ot still is there. (1937)
February 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
y:Ne 2.  V20 Bayard StrSet, slCo:'1g Mrs. Plotters residence.
September 7, 1908.

730665f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730665f-a.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construotion, with the "Catwalk" and Manhattan
anchorage in the foreground. Also shown is a general view westward over
the City Hall and Printing House Souare area, to the Hudson River, with its
Jersey shore line just beyond. Note how the U.S. Post Office and the Tri-
bune Buildings predominated at this date.
About 1878-1879.
Ewing Galloway.

718272f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Mall.
718272f-a.text:
Central Park: The Mall, a view north.
About 1892.
Ewing Galloway.

718806f-a.title: Manhattan: Canal Street - Chrystie Street
718806f-a.text:
A general view northward along Chrystie (left) and Forsyth (right)
Streets, from the Manhattan Bridge, at Canal Street, and showing clearance
for the Sarah Delano Roosevelt Park. Intersecting streets, shown in the ord)r
of their appearance, are Hester, Grand, Broome, Delancey, Rivington, Stanton
and East Houston.
January 14, 1932.
International News Photo.
718806f-a.folder: Canal Street & Chrystie Street, Manhattan, NY

733360f-c.title: Thanksgiving ragamuffins, No.31-33.
733360f-c.text:
(1)
Thanksgiving Ragamuffins, 1933, No. 31. A 1ittle girl applying
lipstick, at 367 Hdson Street, west side, between King and
West Houston Streets.
November 30, 1933.
L. Sperr.
(2)
No. 32. This one got a very liberal application of lipstick.
The location is 381 Hudson Street, in the same block. Notice
the NRA Blue Eagle in the window; these had just come in
that fall.
Novomber 30, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
No. 33. In the same block, a group including the little tyke
shown in No. 32.
November 30, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

731285f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - The Victory Arch.
731285f-a.text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The
Victory Arch on Fifth Avenue at 25th Street as viewed
southward. Thru the center appears the Fullor (Flctiron)
Building. On the right, silhouetted against the Fifth Ave.
Duilding, is the Worth Monument.
1918
Urbrock Collection

713050f-a.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street (West) - 6th Avenue
713050f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, west from but not including Sixth Ave. Also
shown (background) is the 42nd Street station of the Ninth Ave.
Elevated Line.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.

713043f.text:
West 42nd Street, east from Sixth Ave. Overhead is the "I' structure

732193f-a.title: Islands - Welfare Island - [Metropolitan Hospital - City prison.]

718179f-b.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Aerial view from Radio City.
718179f-b.text:
(1)
Central Park: Aerial View from Radio City (Sixth Avenue and 51st
Street), showing the Park and the Fifth Avenue side. In the
center foreground may be seen the Pond, north of it tho l(all,
then the Lake, of which the eastern bay is at thc northern
end of the Mall and the main body on the west side of the
Park, about 70th to 80th Streets. The bare spot further north
is the site of the old reservoir; above it may be seen the nor
reservoir, still in use. The buildings of the Metropolitan
Museum of Art may be seen on the Fifth Avenue side at 81st
Street.
August 9, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, another view. In the southwestern quarter of the
Park may bo seen a ball ground, and north of it the Meadow or
Green. The 72nd Street cross drive separates the Green and
the Lake.
August 9, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718179f-b.folder: Central Park & Aerial view from Radio City., Manhattan, NY

730663f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730663f-a.text:
A general view westward from the Brookl,n Bridge (under construction),
over the Cherry Hill section, Printing House Square, City Hall Commons and
westward to the Hudson (North) River. Shown in the foreground, is the
Manhattan abutment of the bridge, with the Roosevelt Street Ferry to Broad-
way, Brooklyn adjoining. Points of interest shown are, U.S. Post Office,
Tribune Building, Harper's and the Newsboy's Home.
About 1870-1875.
Brown Brothers.
Published in the American on December 1906, and the New York Times
of October 20, 1912.

725900f-a.title: Queens: 150th Street - 147th Avenue
725900f-a.text:
150th Street, west side, north of One Hundred Forty-seventh
Ave. This set consists of four views showing the Christian Nicklaus
farmhouse. For further data, see additional views.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

731081f.title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge - [R. Hoe and Company.]
731081f.text:
The Williamsburg (East River) Bridge under construction as
viewed southeastward from the Manhattan shore. In the foreground
is the area thet will be cleared (1939) for the East Piver Drive.
The R. Hoe and Company foundry on the right will shortly be removed.
About 1903-4
Ewing Galloway

North on Fifth Avenue from S. W. corner of 42nd Street, showing

Bristol Building, formerly Bristol Hotel, at left foreground.
Temple Emanu-l at right centre.

730622f-a.title: Staten Island - Poppy Joe Island Beach - [Stroud place.]
730622f-a.text:
Poppy Joe Island Beach (Staten Islard): A group
of local muskrat Dunters and hunting dogs in front of their
work-and-storage barn. From left to right they are: Louis
Stroud, George W. Stroud, John ('Jaff') Dayis, and James A.
Stroud. Poppy Joe Island is on the Lower Vew York Bay, near
New Creek, between Ocean Breeze and Midland Beach.
About 1911
Photo by J.E. Davis
Copied by P. L. Sperr
730622f-a.folder: Poppy Joe Island Beach, Staten Island, N.Y.

709480f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 42nd Street (West)
709480f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, at W. 42nd Street, showing demelitien of the
Sixth Avenue "El' structure and its 42nd Street station. The
photocrapher is vicwing norbhwestward frem a vantage peint in
Bryant Park towards Times Square whe e the Times Building appears.
April 4, 1939
Mr. Nathan Schwartz

718268f-b.title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Mall.
718268f-b.text:
(1)
Central Park: The Mall, crowd with roller skaters. During this
and the following year, this sport, always more or lesa popular,
suddenly became a craze; young, middle aged, and old, children
and adulta all took to roller skates. The Mall and the
Central Park walks, together with the east sidewalk of Central
Park West, were favorite locations, but by no means the only ones.
May 15, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, annothcr view.
May 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same another view.
The seated statue represents Fitz-Creene Halleck, by Wilson
MacDonald (erected in 1877).
May 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718268f-b.folder: Central Park & The Mall., Manhattan, NY

701498f-b.title: Bronx: Pelham Parkway South - Sacket Avenue
701498f-b.text:
Morris Park Race Track (Bronx); Viewing north across the
fashionable track from near the grand stand. The track wss
bounded on the east by Williamshridge Road; on the west by
Parnes Avenue; on the north by Pelham Parkway; and on the south
by Sacket Avenue. In June, 1913 "the most remarkable real
estate sale in the history of the city", as the New York Times
commented editorially, took place when the track property was
offered for auction by Joseph P. Day and Clarence Davies.
For additional data see "The New York Times," April 27, June 15,
and June 22, 1913.
MAY BE REPRODUCED  About 1910
Views 1,2:
1.
701498f-b.folder: Pelham Parkway South & Sacket Avenue, Bronx, NY

724321f-b.title: Manhattan: Weehawken Street - Christopher Street
724321f-b.text:
(1)
Weehawken Street, west side, from Christopher to 10th Streets.
The view also shows the corner building north side of Christopher
Street, from Weehawken to West Streets.
May 12, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, two years later.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A similar view at a later dat0, showing demolition of Nos. 388
(corner building) and 390 (old 27story building, adjoining) West

May 15, 1937.
